DataElement.preferredName: Residual Disease Post New Tumor Event Margin Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the status of tissue margins following surgical resection for a locoregional procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Residual Disease Post New Neoplasm Status
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made._Post; occuring after._New; having no previous example or precedent or parallel._(TOO-mer) An abnormal mass of tissue that results from excessive cell division. Tumors perform no useful body function. They may be benign (not cancerous) or malignant (cancerous)._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.

Concepts.definition: Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.

Property.preferredDefinition: Post; occuring after.:New; having no previous example or precedent or parallel.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
A condition or state at a particular time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text terms to describe the status of a tissue margin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Data from an original source is not present, accessible or ready for use or service.

Concepts.definition: Data from an original source is not present, accessible or ready for use or service.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of macroscopically visible residual tumor at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.: Visible to the naked eye.: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.

Concepts.definition: The presence of macroscopically visible residual tumor at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.
Visible to the naked eye.
Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.
